Award.AwardTitle: Approximate Dynamic Programming Using Random Sampling

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: Abstract<br/><br/>Proposal Number: ECCS-0824077<br/><br/>Proposal Title: Approximate Dynamic Programming Using Random Sampling <br/><br/>PI Name: Atkeson, Christopher G. <br/><br/>PI Institution: Carnegie-Mellon University<br/><br/>The objective of this research is to develop approximate dynamic<br/>programming methods for the control of high performance nonlinear<br/>systems. The approach is to use spatially local models of key<br/>functions such as a function that represents future costs over an<br/>entire task or mission (the value function), and a function that tells<br/>the system what to do in each situation (the policy). Humanoid robots<br/>will be used to evaluate the nonlinear control design techniques and<br/>compare them with other approximate dynamic programming approaches.<br/><br/>Intellectual Merit<br/><br/>Key contributions of this work will be: 1) Developing an integrated<br/>approach for dynamic planning based on approximate dynamic programming<br/>for high performance systems. 2) Showing how to combine many fast<br/>greedy local planners to produce globally optimal solutions. 3)<br/>Showing how to represent knowledge along explicit trajectories, which<br/>increases the feasible sparseness of this approximate dynamic<br/>programming method. 4) Showing how to create an adaptive<br/>representation using random sampling of states. 5) Showing how to use<br/>local models, and compare them to global parametric function<br/>approximators. 6) Showing how to use fast trajectory optimization to<br/>speed up approximate dynamic programming.<br/><br/>Broader impacts<br/><br/>A specific impact of this work will be to enable high performance<br/>(near optimal) control in areas like robotics, transportation, and<br/>energy. A more general societal payoff is industrial processes,<br/>machines, and robots that are easier to program, perform better and<br/>waste fewer resources.<br/>
